title: Understanding the Gibbs Free Energy Equation
text:
To calculate the Gibbs free energy change for a process, we use the equation:

ΔG $$=$$ ΔH - TΔS

where:
- ΔG is the Gibbs free energy change
- ΔH is the enthalpy change
- T is the temperature in Kelvin
- ΔS is the entropy change

title: Convert Units Appropriately
text: Before substituting the values into the equation, it's important to note that the units of ΔH and ΔS must match. The enthalpy given is in $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$, and the entropy is in $$\frac{J}{K} mol$$.\n\nYou need to convert the enthalpy from $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$ to $$\frac{J}{mol}$$. How can you do that?

title: Convert ΔH from $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$ to $$\frac{J}{mol}$$
text: The molar enthalpy of fusion is $$5.65$$ $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$. Convert this value into $$\frac{J}{mol}$$.

title: Calculate TΔS
text: Now that we know the temperature T and ΔS , calculate the term TΔS . Use the values:\n- T $$=$$ $$170$$ K\n- ΔS $$=$$ $$28.9$$ $$\frac{J}{K} mol$$.

title: Final Calculation of ΔG
text:
Now that you have both values, substitute them into the equation for Gibbs free energy:

ΔG $$=$$ ΔH - TΔS
